DOC.HEADLINE: Norwegian North Sea oil platform being evacuated after gas leak

TEXT.P: More than 160 of 216 people working on a Norwegian oil platform in the North Sea were evacuated Sunday after one of the rigs became "unstable", causing a loss of output of 130,000 barrels per day, a company spokesman and rescue services said.
The group was evacuated by helicopter from the Snorre A platform which is operated by Norway's Statoil, Terje Largaas, a rescue official at Sola in the southwest of the country, told AFP.
"It means that we lost control of the pressure in one of the rigs," after a gas leak around 7:00 pm (1800 GMT), he said.
Three helicopters and four ships were helping evacuate the rest of the staff, Norwegian news agency NTB said.
"We have stopped production" at Snorre A, Kristofer Hetland, a spokesman for Statoil, told AFP.
Hetland could not say when production was expected to resume.
"We are trying to stabilize the situation," he said, adding that the problem appeared to have been fixed four hours after the incident began.
No one was hurt, he said.
The Snorre oil field where the Snorre A and Snorre B platforms are located produces a total 238,000 barrels per day, according to the Statoil website.
Norway is the third crude exporter after Saudi Arabia and Russia and produces nearly three million barrels per day.
